moves.4. Qh5+: g6 would be followed by Qxe5+ and then (White) Qxh8.
moves.4... Ke7: This is the worse move to do in this position. Let the checking begin!
moves.10... Kg7 11. h5:
Threatening 11. ... 12. h6#
Black cannot defend by 11. ... h6 because of 12. Qh6#.
moves.11... Bb4+: Black's only way to prolong the game
moves.12. c3: White's defence does not really matter at this point as long as any attacking pieces are not used.
moves.13. Qg6+ Kf8 14. Qf7#: This shows how dangerous King's Gambit can be to a player who does not know the opening.
